ygData.subject: Re: Three phase equilibrium

Thank you Prof. Goodwin. My colleague is working with C++ interface
for Can=
tera so we may be able to use liquid solution class available
only in C++ v=
ersion. Could you please briefly describe the class in
brief. I am also won=
dering if this class considers positive and
negative ions? 

Thanks.
Chitra=
l 


--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@...> wrote:
>
=
> Defining each liquid species as a stoichiometric liquid is not want  
> y=
ou want to do.  This will give you 40 separate fixed-composition  
> liquid=
 phases. What you want is a single liquid phase solution of 40  
> species.=
 Harry Moffat has added classes for liquid solutions to  
> Cantera, so he =
is probably the best one to answer this.  But  
> unfortunately the hooks t=
o access these classes from Python or MATLAB  
> have not been implemented =
yet, so you are likely to need to work in C+ 
> + to use these...
> 
> 
> O=
n Jan 25, 2007, at 10:44 AM, chitral_naik wrote:
> 
> > Hello,
> >
> > I am=
 trying to solve three phase equilibrium at 1 atm and 350K. My gas
> > phas=
e species (idealgas mix) involve combustion products and halogens.
> > Ther=
e are more than 40 species in liquid phase (I had to define each
> > as sto=
ichiometric liquid) and about 10 solid phase species (each
> > defined as s=
toichiometric solid).
> >
> > When I use multiphase equilibrium, the answer=
 is different from that
> > from popular HSC Chemistry 5.1 program. Has any=
one encountered this
> > problem? Please let me know if you have successful=
ly used a three
> > phase equilibrium solver and compared to HSC or other m=
ultiphase
> > equilibrium solvers.
> >

ixture(phases) to import all phases
